title: 3M Will be Testifying About PFAS at a House Hearing on Water Contamination
text:
Text size

3M shares have had a difficult 2019, due in part to environmental uncertainty.



Investors aren’t sure how to account for PFAS chemical liabilities. Investors, however, might get a better sense of the size of the problem on Tuesday. The House Committee on Oversight and Reform is holding a hearing to discuss PFAS water contamination.

The back story. PFAS, or per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, are chemicals manufactured for years by 3M (ticker: MMM), among others, for use in such products as stain- and water-resistant fabrics and carpeting, as well as paint, until the early 2000s. The Environmental Protection Agency now says PFAS exposure can lead to “adverse health outcomes.” Recently, makers of PFAS chemicals have been setting aside money to clean up manufacturing sites. They are also facing some new product-liability lawsuits.

During the first quarter of 2019, 3M took a $235 million charge for PFAS remediation. Shares dropped 13% after the company reported first-quarter numbers. It wasn’t all due to PFAS though. The company missed Wall Street earnings expectations and cut its full-year profit guidance.

What’s new. 3M representatives are scheduled to testify on Capitol Hill and on Monday and issued a news release listing new PFAS actions, including money for research and remediation.

“These initiatives are guided by 3M’s long history of corporate responsibility and our commitment to sound science,” said Dr. Rutherford, senior vice president of Corporate Affairs, in the company’s news release. “I look forward to sharing 3M’s commitment and knowledge with the Subcommittee. We will continue to work with Congress and regulators to address PFAS concerns.”

Looking ahead. It will take more clarity on the PFAS issue to get the stock working again. Shares are down 13% year to date, worse than the 17% gain of the Dow Jones Industrial Average over the same span. Shares trade for 16.4 times estimated 2020 earnings, a discount to historical averages, but in line with other industrial stocks in the S&P 500.

3M shares rose 1.2% to $165.94 on Monday, better than the 0.1% gain for the Dow.

description: Representatives of 3M are scheduled to testify on Tuesday at an environmental hearing on Capitol Hill. On Monday the company issued a news release listing new PFAS actions, including money for research and remediation.
